issue.title: base support for custom ransackers

repository.name: activeadmin
repository.description: The administration framework for Ruby on Rails applications.

issue.body:
## Given:

``` ruby
class User < ActiveRecord::Base
  # attribute email
  ransacker :fullname do
    Arel.sql("CONCAT(`firstname`, ' ',`lastname`)")
  end
end

ActiveAdmin.register User do
  filter :fullname
  filter :email
end
```
## Before this PR ActiveAdmin only renders a filter field for email, not for fullname:

![before_pr_without_fullname](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/165599/4777993/6ca6710a-5bda-11e4-9661-73722a00a032.jpg)
## After this PR ActiveAdmin provides a search field for fullname:

![after_pr_with_fullname](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/165599/4778036/89b2f31c-5bdb-11e4-9158-70c3aa73f44f.jpg)

I'm working on even more support for custom ransackers.

This solves #3509 and #3510.

body:
A base support is now implemented by #3516.
It now supports a basic search field for custom ransackers (green), I'm working on a full level support (red).
![pasted_image_19_11_14_01_27](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/165599/5098797/73e0f7aa-6f8b-11e4-946a-7c8ae4c89413.jpg)

Awesome! 

A somewhat related issue is this https://github.com/activeadmin/activeadmin/issues/3661. Been driving me crazy for the last few hours, didn't make much progress on it.

issue.title: Ransacker Filter additional predicates don't work

repository.name: activeadmin
repository.description: The administration framework for Ruby on Rails applications.

issue.body:
We have an amount stored in the database as cents. I want to be able to search things in dollars. Therefore I created this

``` ruby
class Order < ActiveRecord::Base
  ransacker :total_amount_in_dollars, formatter: proc {|v| (v.to_f * 100).round }, type: :numeric do |parent|
    parent.table[:total_amount]
  end
end
```

In `app/admin/order.rb` I have:

``` ruby
ActiveAdmin.register Order do
   filter :total_amount_in_dollars
end
```

This generate a filter but the predicts for `gt` and `lt` don't render properly. Ransack handles it properly, but something in the rendering sequence is not working. I tried looking into it, but couldn't find exactly where things were going wrong. I know it is something to do with how `FilterNumericInput` renders values.

body: It is :). Thanks! Let us know when your done so I can remove this temporary workaround.
@yagudaev simply track the status of this issue

issue.title: Problem with custom numeric filter

repository.name: activeadmin
repository.description: The administration framework for Ruby on Rails applications.

issue.body:
Hi!

activeadmin (1.0.0.pre)
ransack (1.5.1)

models/rental.rb:

``` ruby
ransacker :duration_equals, formatter: -> (opt) {
                              sql = "SELECT id FROM rentals WHERE (DATE_PART('day', rental_end_time::timestamp - rental_start_time::timestamp) * 24 +
      DATE_PART('hour', rental_end_time::timestamp - rental_start_time::timestamp)) * 60 +
      DATE_PART('minute', rental_end_time::timestamp - rental_start_time::timestamp) = #{opt}"
                              data = ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute(sql)
                              data.present? ? Rental.find(data) : nil
                            }, splat_params: true do |parent|
    parent.table[:id]
  end

  ransacker :duration_greater_than, formatter: -> (opt) {
                                    sql = "SELECT id FROM rentals WHERE (DATE_PART('day', rental_end_time::timestamp - rental_start_time::timestamp) * 24 +
      DATE_PART('hour', rental_end_time::timestamp - rental_start_time::timestamp)) * 60 +
      DATE_PART('minute', rental_end_time::timestamp - rental_start_time::timestamp) >= #{opt}"
                                    data = ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute(sql)
                                    data.present? ? Rental.find(data) : nil
                                  }, splat_params: true do |parent|
    parent.table[:id]
  end

  ransacker :duration_less_than, formatter: -> (opt) {
                                 sql = "SELECT id FROM rentals WHERE (DATE_PART('day', rental_end_time::timestamp - rental_start_time::timestamp) * 24 +
      DATE_PART('hour', rental_end_time::timestamp - rental_start_time::timestamp)) * 60 +
      DATE_PART('minute', rental_end_time::timestamp - rental_start_time::timestamp) <= #{opt}"
                                 data = ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute(sql)
                                 data.present? ? Rental.find(data) : nil
                               }, splat_params: true do |parent|
    parent.table[:id]
  end
```

admin/rentals.rb:

``` ruby
  filter :duration, as: :numeric
```

It seems that duration_equals, duration_greater_than or duration_less_than are never called. If I delete one I have an error.
If I add a ransacker called "duration", this one is called but I can't know if it comes from "equals", "greater" or "less"... 

``` ruby
[55] pry(main)> p
=> {"duration_gteq"=>"15", "duration_lteq"=>"20"}
[56] pry(main)> r = Rental.ransack p
=> Ransack::Search<class: Rental, base: Grouping <conditions: [Condition <predicate: gteq, values: ["15"]>, Condition <predicate: lteq, values: ["20"]>], combinator: and>>
```

There is no "attributes" in the Ransack::Search object.

Thank you for your help!

issue.title: Bug in 'seems_searchable?' / ransack-related

repository.name: activeadmin
repository.description: The administration framework for Ruby on Rails applications.

issue.body:
When I create a custom ransacker in my model:

```
  ransacker :last_signup_step do
    Arel.sql("company_meta->>'lastSignupStep'")
  end
```

And then a filter in ActiveAdmin:

```
filter :last_signup_step, as: :numeric
```

It works, but it always does the equals comparison, even if I select something else from the dropdown. It seems because the `select_and_search` css class is not added to the field.
This comes from this line from ActiveAdmin source: `(opts[:class] ||= '') << ' select_and_search' unless seems_searchable?`

The method `seems_searchable?` returns true if there is a ransacker defined with that name, I think that is causing the issue. Maybe it was bugged after ransack was introduced? I think the metasearch methods were named like `field_equals` but in ransacker it's just `field`.

issue.title: Filters using custom ransacker not showing in sidebar

repository.name: activeadmin
repository.description: The administration framework for Ruby on Rails applications.

issue.body:
I have some filters that use a custom ransacker. Filtering works, but when submitting the form upon reload all the fields are blank. I tried it with the most basic example from ransack and I still have the issue.

In my model:

``` ruby
ransacker :reversed_title, formatter: proc { |v| v.reverse } do |parent|
  parent.table[:title]
end
```

In my controller

``` ruby
filter :reversed_title, :as => :string
```

Now if I do a search the items are filtered correctly in the list view, but the contents of the checkbox are erased. The parameter is passed correctly in the quest url:

http://localhost:3000/admin/mymodel?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q%5Breversed_title%5D=test

I passed a couple hours poling through ActiveAdmin but I'm, stuck. It seems some magic happens in `get_parent_and_attribute_name` in Ransack::Adapters::ActiveRecord, where it tries to match the filter name to the model columns, and does not find it.
I looked through the Any ideas?

body: Is there any chance to have the problem fixed? I had to do a very ugly javascript workaround to get the searched filter value in the textbox

issue.title: Update filters to work with custom Ransackers

repository.name: activeadmin
repository.description: The administration framework for Ruby on Rails applications.

issue.body:
It seems that ransackers (eg `ransacker :name_reversed`) are _not_ expected to be called without predicates (that is, they **are** called with predicates, eg: `name_reversed_cont`). So a ransacker filter without a predicate should not `seems_searchable?`.

Seems to me that custom ransackers would never have worked as intended with this code  an artifact of converting from metasearch without testing it in a sample application.

[fixes #3510 / #3409]

body:
Added a pull request. As @timoschilling points out above, the comment on #3409 does suggest a workaround; but that workaround is a little brute force, and you may get confusing filter issues since any filter that's not a ransacker will `seems_searchable?`. If you want to fix this issue now, use this in an initializer:

``` ruby
module ActiveAdmin
  module Filters
    module FormtasticAddons
      def seems_searchable?
        has_predicate? || scope?
      end
    end
  end
end
```
